awd_titl_txt: Conference: Organizing 2024 International Conference on Quantum Fluids and Solids
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports registration fees and other associated costs for graduate students, as well as for female and under-represented minority participants who are in need of financial support, to attend and present at the 2024 International Conference on Quantum Fluids and Solids (QFS), which will be held in Jacksonville, Florida. The conference will bring together a community of students and scientists to discuss a broad range of condensed matter systems that exhibit quantum mechanical effects at the macroscopic level, including superfluids, superconductors and atomic Bose-Einstein condensates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The 2024 International Symposium on Quantum Fluids and Solids (QFS2024), supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF), was held from July 24-30, 2024, at the Hyatt Regency Jacksonville Riverfront in Florida. This premier event, prominently featured on its dedicated website at www.qfs2024.org, successfully convened 172 participants from 15 countries, representing a wide spectrum of expertise in quantum physics and engineering. The symposium served as a pivotal platform for disseminating cutting-edge research and fostering extensive international collaboration across the quantum fluids and solids community.

Intellectual Merit: QFS2024 significantly advanced our understanding of quantum phenomena through a robust academic program that included 49 invited talks, 29 contributed talks, and 70 poster presentations. The topics covered ranged from traditional studies of superfluidity and quantum turbulence to innovative explorations of quantum fluids and solids in quantum computing. Esteemed researchers and emergent scientists shared their latest findings, pushing the boundaries of quantum science and bridging fundamental research with practical technological applications. This event not only highlighted the current state of the field but also set the agenda for future research directions, emphasizing interdisciplinary approaches and the integration of new technologies.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of QFS2024 were profound, influencing education, policy, and industry:

  • Educational and Economic Development: The symposium was particularly noteworthy for its efforts to support the next generation of scientists. The registration fee for students was significantly reduced to $150, compared to $550 for other participants, and a subsidy of $300 per person was provided for accommodations. This financial assistance was instrumental in enabling broader participation from students and early-career researchers, who are vital for the continued vitality of the scientific community.

  • Networking and Professional Growth: The symposium organizers arranged several excursions, including trips to the Kennedy Space Center and historic St. Augustine. These outings were highly acclaimed for providing unique networking opportunities in relaxed, informal settings, allowing participants to forge new collaborations and discuss potential research ventures outside the conventional conference environment.

  • Recognition of Emerging Researchers: The conference highlighted the contributions of young researchers through a competitive poster session. Nine outstanding posters were recognized, with the recipients awarded certificates and special prizes that acknowledged their innovative work and encouraged further academic pursuit.

  • Social and Cultural Exchange: A banquet featuring a keynote speech by renowned physicist Robert Hallock emphasized the communal and historical significance of the quantum fluids and solids research community. This event celebrated past achievements and looked forward to the future of the field, enhancing the sense of community among participants.

Organizing Committees: The organization of QFS2024 was meticulously planned and executed by co-chairs Prof. Wei Guo (Florida State University) and Prof. Yoonseok Lee (University of Florida). They were supported by an extensive committee system that included local program committees and international advisory boards, ensuring that the symposium’s scientific agenda was both rigorous and inclusive. The committees were instrumental in curating a diverse range of topics and speakers, reflecting the global and interdisciplinary nature of the field.

Summary of Award Outcomes: QFS2024 achieved significant milestones, enhancing the field of quantum fluids and solids through international collaboration and scientific exchange. The symposium facilitated groundbreaking discussions and provided a platform for the dissemination of innovative research. It supported over 170 participants, including many students and early-career scientists, by offering a forum to share their work, receive feedback, and develop professional networks. The proceedings and materials from the symposium continue to serve as a valuable resource for the global scientific community.

This symposium set a high standard for future conferences in terms of its organizational excellence, scientific impact, and commitment to fostering the next generation of scientists. It provided invaluable opportunities for professional development and set the stage for future technological advancements in the field.

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2024
Modified by: Wei Guo
